title: Introduction to the Mcomp package
text: M1 forecasting competition organized Spyros Makridakis Michèle Hibon, involving 1001 series. competition, anyone submit forecasts, making first true forecasting competition far aware. also used multiple forecast measures determine accurate method. 1001 time series taken demography, industry economics, ranged length 9 132 observations. data either non-seasonal (e.g., annual), quarterly monthly. Curiously, data positive, made possibly compute mean absolute percentage errors, really reflective population real data. M1 competition data stored M1. Functions provided plot manage date. plot.Mdata() autoplot.Mdata() functions plot time series, showing training test sections series.   subset.Mcomp() returns subset time series data; subsets can specific periods, specific types data . 111 series used extended comparisons 1982 M-competition can also selected. M1 class Mcomp list, element also list containing information one time series. example, first element contains following information. various items follows: st: series number period. example Y1 denotes first yearly series, Q20 denotes 20th quarterly series, ; n: number observations training part time series; h: number required forecasts (equivalently number observations test part time series); period: interval time series. Possible values YEARLY, QUARTERLY, MONTHLY & . type: type series. Possible values DEMOGR, INDUST, MACRO1, MACRO2, MICRO1, MICRO2 & MICRO3. description: short description time series; x: training part time series length n; xx: test part time series length h. sn: name series;

title: Introduction to the Mcomp package
text: 1998, Makridakis & Hibon ran M3 competition. Entrants forecast 3003 time series results compared test set withheld participants. time series taken business, demography, finance economics, ranging length 14 126 observations. , data either non-seasonal (e.g., annual), quarterly monthly, positive. time series M3 forecasting competition forecasts original participating methods stored M3 M3Forecast respectively. plot.Mdata(), autoplot.Mdata() subset.Mcomp() work M3 well. structure M3 M1. M3Forecast list data.frames. list element result one forecasting method. data.frame following structure. row forecast one series; rows named accordingly. column corresponds forecast horizon. 18 columns, maximum number forecasts series 18. fewer forecasts 18 exist, row padded NA values.

title: M3-Competition forecasts of original competition participants — M3Forecast
code: M3Forecast[["NAIVE2"]][1,] #>            V1      V2      V3      V4      V5      V6 V7 V8 V9 V10 V11 V12 V13 #> N0001 4936.99 4936.99 4936.99 4936.99 4936.99 4936.99 NA NA NA  NA  NA  NA  NA #>       V14 V15 V16 V17 V18 #> N0001  NA  NA  NA  NA  NA  if (FALSE) { # calculate errors using the accuracy function # from the forecast package  errors <- lapply(M3Forecast, function(f) {       res <- NULL       for(x in 1:length(M3)) {         curr_f <- unlist(f[x,])         if(any(!is.na(curr_f))) {           curr_res <- accuracy(curr_f, M3[[x]]$xx)         } else {           # if no results are available create NA results           curr_res <- accuracy(M3[[x]]$xx, M3[[x]]$xx)           curr_res <- rep(NA, length(curr_res))         }         res <- rbind(res, curr_res)       }       rownames(res) <- NULL       res     })  ind_yearly <- which(unlist(lapply(M3, function(x) {x$period == "YEARLY"}))) ind_quarterly <- which(unlist(lapply(M3, function(x) {x$period == "QUARTERLY"}))) ind_monthly <- which(unlist(lapply(M3, function(x) {x$period == "MONTHLY"}))) ind_other <- which(unlist(lapply(M3, function(x) {x$period == "OTHER"})))  yearly_errors <- t(as.data.frame(lapply(errors, function(x) {colMeans(x[ind_yearly,])}))) quarterly_errors <- t(as.data.frame(lapply(errors, function(x) {colMeans(x[ind_quarterly,])}))) monthly_errors <- t(as.data.frame(lapply(errors, function(x) {colMeans(x[ind_monthly,])}))) other_errors <- t(as.data.frame(lapply(errors, function(x) {colMeans(x[ind_other,])})))  yearly_errors quarterly_errors monthly_errors other_errors }
